The by products of fossil fuels. first lets stop calling it fossil fuel it's natural oil, coal and gas. Oil, coal and gas are used for more then fuel. We convert them into by products such as plastics which in my opinion should be out lawed. In it molecular state it is still a toxic waste. The earth can't recycle it into any natural state and reuse it. Other by products of oil, coal and gas  such as chemicals, synthetics, sealers, paints, dyes, make up,  etc. Just to name a few.  That are used in production and manufacturing, goods and services. Green energy will need these things to even build the components for a green energy infrastructure. You can not convert solar or wind into any of these by products to make the components to build a green energy infrastructure. One of the most environmentally hazardous things in the world is batteries. Green energy stores energy in power cells (batteries) it is low voltage and low amperage electricity. text: ¬†@Arthur Morgan¬† I understand your anger with the actions of the FED but I find it interesting that you make Tesla your focal point.  The American economic system is related to the actions of the FED.  I'd much rather Tesla be pumped up than Exxon and Mobil but they all are.  As you say, no pumping would be best.  I imagine you advocate abolishing the FED right?  So what would have happened without it?  I would also guess you are wealthy and can more easily weather a depression. author: Raw and Cooked Vegan

text:
¬†@Raw and Cooked Vegan¬† Lol, I'm not at all wealthy largely thanks to the actions of the Fed. Yes, I want to see the Fed abolished, a gold standard monetary system reinstated, free markets & price discovery. 

Depressions come about because of debt, which in turn comes about when central banksters debase the currency, push interest rates to zero, encourage leveraged speculation in asset markets, rob wage earners, rob pension holders as they draw down.

I propose an alternative gold based monetary system, a ~2% wealth tax (one personal residence & one personal transport exempted), abolish all other forms of taxation including CGT, sales tax, corporate tax etc. The proceeds of the wealth tax to be redistributed to poor & sick people. The rest of government to be cut back massively & people to form civil enterprises with opt-in subscriptions to provide municipal services, healthcare, education.

I would also illegalize all forms of debt or interest based financing, to be replaced by equity based finance and venture capital.
author: Arthur Morgan

text: ¬†@Arthur Morgan¬† Interesting.  Do you consider BTC as a potential way to shift away from fiat currency?  A digital gold that cannot be devalued.
author: Raw and Cooked Vegan

text: ¬†@Raw and Cooked Vegan¬† I can‚Äôt make my mind up about bitcoin. In many ways it is far superior to gold as a unit of account, but it has some very big deal-breaking problems. Its not a quantum resistant platform, its almost entirely owned & used by a new tech elite & not ordinary folk, it has worrying parallels to a pump & dump scheme, its currently a manipulated fraudulent market where a few whales can instigate huge price moves, a large fraction of bitcoin is permanently lost forever, there is no mechanism to pass on inherited wealth without compromising your private keys. It‚Äôs not easily taxed & appears incompatible with the existence of sovereign nation states.

author: Mike Brophy

text:
Glad I bought Tesla 18 months ago. 
This is how you lower carbon emissions: through capitalism, free markets, trade, innovation, research and development - not through spending of trillions of dollars on the Green New Deal. Though FDR's policies were necessary in the 1930s and pulled America out of a Global Depression, new government spending polices won't solve the problem of carbon emissions. We have this fascination with the past, but what worked 90 years ago is no longer applicable today. After the '29 market crash, within months the country became a 2-tier society of haves and those way under the poverty line and not able to make a living wage. Plus, socially, America was able to have most of its people move in the same direction  - that's no longer possible. When America is no longer #1 in the world in New Development, Innovation and Research, it will be the beginning of the end of our Great Republic. The government is slowly becoming the architect of our lives, not the individual.

¬†@Daniel Gillis¬† Tesla is the first company I've ever bet against. Just to clarify, I did not short it because it can still rally. I bought a put option at $400 instead.

The bet is essentially $1280 for the potential to win $40,000 if it goes bankrupt. If it stays afloat and share price drops to say $150 I make $25,000. If the price goes up, I am out $1280. I only need to be right more than 3.1%-4.9% to make it a worth while bet.

All this must happen by July 16 of this year. Most likely scenario is price falls to $150, but bankruptcy is not out of the possibility.

For what it is worth, I actually don't want Tesla to go bankrupt, I'd rather the stock price just get back to reality. It actually would be pretty cool to own a Tesla one day, given that the company can survive future trials.
author: Kyle Mart

text: ¬†@Kyle Mart¬† this is what I'm talking about, yes ofc the potential of making a good profit if right is huge, but the chances are literally also nonexistent, you're thinking about PnL instead of probabilities. text: Not about climate change to me.  Autonomous vehicles will be a huge transportation system transformer.  Starship will also be transformational to the Space industry dropping cost to space 2 order of magnitude.  Starlink isn't just about providing global satellite internet, but utilizing his reusable launch ability, the cheapness of getting up a constellation.  Now its 60 sats per launch, and with starship it will be 400 sats per launch.  I had already predicted many other applications for cheap satellite constellations upon the 1st announcement and already some have come forward.  Military defense applications are abundant with sensor and communication (e.g. hypersonic vehicle tracking, low latency command and control of remote robots, drones, etc., but also stuff like fine sensor analysis for weather (e.g. cloud cover monitoring)).  Once you get costs down like Elon is causing to happen (I call Starship the model T of spaceships), vast vistas of applications open up, including space tourism and off planet settlement.  I think SpaceX will ultimately become the most valuable company on Earth (but serving the solar system).

A new set of tyrants coming in with a new vision, well Hooray for now, but it will take a lifetime to realize that the same old outcome will result. text:
So many problems with the narrative here. 
First, the headline, as all these CEO net worth headlines, is highly misleading because the founder-CEO can not sell his shares at anywhere near the current price. By selling he would crash the price and therefore the figure is completely unrealiseable.
Second, Telsa is a government created mutant zombie monster. If interest rates were not negative this business would not be worth diddly squat. Tesla's primary source of profit is regulatory credits not even cars, let alone all the other futuristic stuff they talk about and never deliver. At the core it is massively loss making and is being propped up by the government.
Third, sorry nobody really needs electric cars and this whole push to EVs is a gargantuan waste of research and development funding that future generations will have to pay for.
Happy camping kids!

Viable, by definition, is based on a company and their ability to continue to grow.
Tesla has that in spades. They HAVE and WILL continue to grow the number of vehicles produced EVERY YEAR...like they have the past decade.
They HAVE and WILL continue to grow the number of Production Facilities (both in numbers and in size) they have around the world.
Tesla HAS and WILL continue to create new models, products, Software, Upgrades and many other offerings they can SELL in the future as they expand their markets well beyond light passenger vehicles.
Not heeding what Chamath P., the Warren Buffett of new Tech is foolish. 
Whether the stock remains at this buoyant level or goes sideways for a while...
Tesla is Certainly ‚ÄúVIABLE‚Äù...

text:
¬†@Jonas Schroder¬† This is NOTHING like Mortgage Bond FRAUD. That was the issue...
People unqualified to actually get loans were buying houses. Builders were building WAY more than could be sold.
Tesla has barely scratched the surface of the passenger auto industry, the battery storage industry, the solar power generation industry, the software industry and the power arbitrage industry. 
They will also be putting self driving into place within this decade.
There is NO OVERSUPPLY of EVs currently. There is, in fact, a SHORTAGE of available, high performance EVs. Same for Battery Storage, same for Distributed Energy Generation.
Is the price currently too high...probably...
are the prices of the current OEMs WAY too high as some head for self-destruction by delaying their entry into EVs...and the Oil Industry not getting moves on to the next evolution in Energy?? Absolutely...
Exxon is cratering in value for a reason...so is Ford, so will Toyota and others who delay EVs.
Cheers

text: ¬†@Justin Madonna¬† you obviously don't pay attention to Elon's work huh? If he didn't care about the environment, he wouldn't build one of the most valuable EV companies in the world to help transition from fossil fueled cars to electric fueled cars. You obviously don't know about the huge Tesla battery farm plant in southern Australia that has saves millions of dollars in electricity bills for the rural communities and has protected the environment there. You obviously don't know about Tesla's acquisition of SolarCity which focuses on creating solar roof panels so that our homes are designed to support the environment and invested in sustainable tech. One of the sole reason we should also be invested into the expansion of space exploration, in which Neil deGrasse Tyson has mentioned before, earth's civilization will become extinct whether by natural external factors such as intense heat from the sun or an asteroid, or by invasive human development. Why can't we do all we can on Earth to protect it while also investing into expanding our boundaries in case we fail Earth? That is what I call diversification.

text: Of course we do. Those other revenue streams may only be 5% today, but Chamath's whole point is that those sources have massive growth potential over the next decade and will eclipse the EV revenue.  You're saying the same thing people have been saying for years and will continue to claim for years to come about Tesla.  "Competition is coming! There is no moat!", "Just wait! It's coming!"  We'll be waiting for decades. The other automakers have actually been trying, and they're coming up short.  They can't vertically integrate.  They design by committee and move like a dinosaur.  Tesla's AI, battery tech, drivetrain tech, software engineering and so on are years ahead of anyone else in terms of mass production at high margins.  It's just laughable to hear someone say "Tesla has no moat".

text: Tesla is a great example of a "Greater fool investment". As Warren Buffett says if you have a sound investment you won't care what others think of your company. And here they come.  This is a cut and paste from another vid but it probably applies to naysayers everywhere in general:

I‚Äôm only five minutes in and won‚Äôt come back to finish until tomorrow, but so far they‚Äôre only talking about Tesla car sales and vehicles not justifying the company valuation.  Has anyone asked how Tesla‚Äôs grid battery storage megapack and industrial megapack sales to governments and industries all over the world are going?  Several state governments in Australia have made multiple fifty million dollar single contract purchases of Tesla megapacks for their grid storage battery farms attached to wind and solar renewables over the last few years, and that‚Äôs just one small country.  How are the Tesla solar glass roofs selling in the US and overseas?  Why is everyone just focusing on vehicles which is only half of what the Tesla brand sells?  Is VW and GM making grid storage and industrial battery megapacks and solar glass roofing and developing all of its software to operate these services in house as part of subscription packages that add to profitability via recurring revenue?
